questions.text: The mortality indicator which represents the ‘killing power’ of a disease is-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Case fatality rate Case fatality is the total number of deaths due to a particular disease out of the total number of cases due to the same disease. It represents the killing power of a disease. Case fatality rate is typically used in acute infectious diseases.

questions.text: The population of a city is approximately 1,00,000 there are around 10,000 cases of diabetes mellitus. In the year 2020, 500 new cases were added. What is the incidence rate of diabetes mellitus in the city for that year?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

5 per 1000 per year = 500/1,00,000 = 5 per 1000 per year

questions.text: All of the following are mortality indicators except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

DALY DALY (Disability-Adjusted Life Years) – Years lost due to ill health/disability – It is a disability rate Hence, among the given options, option D, DALY is not a mortality indicator. Mortality indicators: Crude death rate Expectation of life Age-specific death rate Infant mortality rate Child death rate U-5 proportional mortality rate MMR PMR IMR Years of potential life lost

questions.text: Research showed that Coronary Heart disease is the cause of 25 to 30% of all deaths in Western countries. This is a:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Proportional mortality rate The proportional mortality rate is the simplest measure of estimating the community's disease burden . It includes the proportion of all deaths. In the question, CHD is responsible for 25 to 30% of all deaths. Hence, the given statement indicates a proportional mortality rate.

questions.text: All of the following are measures of mortality EXCEPT-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Secondary Attack Rate The secondary Attack rate (SAR) is defined as the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the incubation period range following exposure to the primary case. So, it is not a measure of mortality but a measure of the spread of an infection within a family, household, or any closed aggregate of persons who have had contact with a case of disease. The following are the measures of mortality: Crude death rate Infant mortality rate Age-specific death rate Infant mortality rate Child death rate Proportionate mortality rate Maternal mortality rate Case fatality rate

questions.text: In a community development block area with a population of 1 Lakh, there were 500 cases of Tuberculosis & 5 cases of rabies. During the same year, there were a total of 100 deaths, out of which five were due to rabies & 50 due to tuberculosis. The case fatality rate of Tuberculosis & rabies, respectively, is-
In a particular year during which the mid-year population of a country was 1000 Lakh, the total deaths due to tuberculosis were 0.5 Lakh, i.e., 0.5 deaths per 1000 population. This is-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cause-specific mortality rate The cause-specific mortality rate is calculated as the number of deaths occurring in a defined area due to a particular disease for every mid-year So, the parameter given here is the Specific death rate due to tuberculosis. Proportionate mortality rate gives the proportion of total deaths due to a given case out of the total deaths. It is calculated as the total deaths due to a particular disease in a defined area over the given time divided by the total deaths (due to all causes) in that area during that time. Case fatality rate is calculated as the number of persons dying due to a particular disease during a defined period in a defined area per 1000 cases of that disease. Crude death rate gives the number of deaths in a defined community in a year per 1000 population in the middle of the year.

questions.text: In Village A, a Survey, "The incidence rate of a disease X is seven times greater in women as compared to men, but the prevalence rates show no difference in men and women.” The best explanation is that:

options.label: A
options.text: The case fatality rate for this disease is lower in women

options.label: B
options.text: The duration of the disease is shorter in men

options.label: C
options.text: The case fatality rate for this disease is higher for women

options.label: D
options.text: Risk factors for developing the disease are more common in women

questions.correct_answer: C. The case fatality rate for this disease is higher for women
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The case fatality rate for this disease is higher for women Since The incidence rate of a disease X is seven times greater in women as compared to men, the prevalence rates show no difference in men and women. So P = I x d Thus, d (duration of disease) must be lower among females Either the disease is more fatal among females, or The disease is easily curable among females

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option:A. If the case fatality rate for the Disease is lower in women, then the Prevalence will be higher in Women. Option:B. Duration of Disease can’t be shorter in Men because it will lead to a decrease in Prevalence Option:C. The case fatality rate for this disease is higher for women, which will maintain the Higher Incidence with the same Prevalence.

questions.text: Which statement given below is correct about the given Image?
questions.correct_answer: A. Incidence would include cases – 3,4,5 and 8
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Incidence would include cases – 3,4,5 and 8 Incidence would include cases - 3,4,5 and 8 Po int prevalence (Jan 1) cases - 1,2 and 7 Po int prevalence (Dec.31) cases - 1,3,5 and 8 Period prevalence (Jan-Dec) cases - 1,2,3,4,5, 7 and 8

questions.text: A randomized control trial showed an effective treatment against cancer, and it was then incorporated by a hospital. Which of the following is subsequently expected to happen?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Decrease in prevalence Cross-sectional studies may be employed to study associations between different diseases or factors, but they cannot determine which might have occurred first. The prevalence rate of a disease can be defined as the proportion of persons in a population who have the disease in question at a particular point in time (point prevalence) or over a short time period (period prevalence). Since an effective treatment is available, it will reduce the total number of patients, thereby decreasing the prevalence. As the number of new cases remains the same, the incidence remains the same.

questions.text: True about prevalence are all except:

options.label: B
options.text: Specifically for old and new cases

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rate Prevalence: the term prevalence refers specifically to all current cases (old and new) existing at a given time or over a period in a given population. Although referred to as a rate, prevalence is actually a ratio. Prevalence = incidence x duration Uses of prevalence:- Estimate the magnitude of health/disease problems in the community among a high-risk group Useful for administrative and planning purposes Also, remember, the Incidence of a disease is a rate in the true sense.

questions.text: A person develops a method that can decrease the morality of disease but not cure it. Which is a true statement?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prevalence should Increase Incidence measures the rate at which new cases are occurring in a population. The duration of the disease does not influence it. Improvements in treatment may decrease the duration of illness and thereby decrease the prevalence of a disease. But if the treatment is such that preventing death and at the same time not producing recovery, it may give rise to the apparently paradoxical effect of an increase in prevalence. Further, if the duration is decreased sufficiently, a decrease in prevalence could take place despite an increase in incidence Decrease In Mortality - Prevalence Will Increase.

questions.text: In which of the given illness incidence rate is likely to be more than the prevalence rate?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rabies If the disease is acute and of short duration, either because of rapid recovery or death, The prevalence rate will be relatively low compared with the incidence rate. In some diseases (E.g., food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived there are no ·old'" cases. The same is true of rapidly fatal conditions, such as homicides. Survival of rabies patients is not there. There is 100% mortality. Hence there are no old cases.

questions.text: The numerator is not a component of the denominator in which of the following indicators-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sex ratio The sex ratio is the number of females per 1000 males. So, here the numerator is the number of females, and the denominator is the number of males. The numerator is not a part of the denominator. The crude death rate is the number of deaths per 1000 population per year in a given So, here the numerator is part of th e denominator.

questions.text: Which of the following measures the burden of disease in a defined population and the effectiveness of interventions?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Disability-adjusted life year Disability-Adjusted Life Years[DALYs]: It is a measure of the burden of disease in a defined population and the effectiveness of intervention It expresses years lost to premature death and years lived with disability-adjusted for its’ severity DALYs = YLL + YLD DALYs can measure ‘both mortality and disability together.’

options.label: B
options.text: One lost year of healthy life

questions.correct_answer: B. One lost year of healthy life
questions.explanation:
Solution:

One lost year of healthy life It expresses years lost to premature death and years lived with disability-adjusted for its’ severity. DALYs = YLL + YLD DALYs can measure ‘both mortality and disability together.’ 1 DALYs = one year of healthy life lost

questions.text: The following is not a utilization marker:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Population bed ratio Efficiency measures how well resources (money, men, material, and time) are utilized to achieve a given effectiveness. The following examples will illustrate the number of immunizations provided in a year compared to an accepted norm; the percentage of bed occupancy, cost per day in the hospital, cost per patient treated, etc. A few examples of utilization rates are cited below: The proportion of infants who are "fully immunized" against the 9 EPI diseases. The proportion of pregnant women who receive antenatal care or have their deliveries supervised by a trained birth attendant. Percentage of the population using the various methods of family planning. Bed-occupancy rate (i.e., average daily in-patient census/average number of beds).' The average length of stay (i.e., days of care rendered/discharges), and Bed turnover ratio (i.e., discharges/average beds)
